awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Interdisciplinary Program in Multi-scale Biological Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Rice University, located in Houston, TX, will support the training of 12 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019 - 2021. This program will expose students to the contributions made by different science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) disciplines toward the detailed understanding of living systems as integrated networks. Students will work in laboratories that draw from an array of approaches - from classical biochemistry and genetics to complex theoretical modeling. Research areas include: (i) biomolecular structure, function, and evolution, (ii) naturally-occurring genetic networks, (iii) synthetic biology and metabolic networks, and (iv) ecological networks. Participating faculty mentors come from a range of departments including Biosciences, Bioengineering, Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering, Chemistry, and Computer Science. This program seeks to recruit students who are training across a similar spectrum of disciplines. Students will also participate in workshops focusing on ethics and responsible conduct of research, professional communication, and the graduate school application process. Application to the program requires a transcript, resume, research statement, and two letters of recommendation. Participants will be selected by a faculty committee, which will assess student alignment with the program based on demonstrated excellence in STEM coursework. 
		
It is anticipated that a total of 36 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will be recruited nationwide, with an emphasis on students enrolled at proximal minority-serving institutions, including community colleges and four-year institutions. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. 

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting https://ibb.rice.edu/nsf-reu-bionetworks, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Joff Silberg at joff@rice.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Natasha Kirienko at kirienko@rice.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
There are multiple challenges associated with training the future generation of biological researchers in the tools that will be critical to solving problems in this field. Current strategies that simply focus on modifying undergraduate curriculum have been limited in the pace at which they achieve their goals. With this approach, students often do not choose the more quantitative tracks that become available within their biological major because their excitement was not stimulated before they declared that major. In addition, students that pursue such tracks often do not obtain enough depth in quantitative concepts to serve them well in their future careers. To overcome this challenge, a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Sites was coordinated at Rice University that provided research training for a dozen students per summer, for ten weeks during the summers of 2019-2013. This approach was used to provide students earlier exposure to the importance of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics in biological research. 

Students were recruited nationwide, with particular emphasis on students enrolled at proximal minority-serving two- and four-year institutions. Extensive efforts were made to recruit from two-year community college institutions, including proximal institutions with large enrollments (>100,000 students), such as Houston Community College, Lone Star College, and San Jacinto College. Selection of students was done based on the faculty steering committee’s evaluation of each applicant’s transcript and recommendation letters. Rice’s Institute of Biosciences and Bioengineering (IBB) administered this NSF REU Program. Efforts were made to recruit from diverse groups. During the period of this award, more than half of the interns were from underrepresented groups and more than half of the interns were enrolled at schools that lack research opportunities such as two-year institutions. Additionally, approximately half of the interns were first generation college students.

This topical focus of this program was biological networks, complex interactions among biomolecules that give rise to the diverse biological phenotypes observed in nature. Students worked on research projects under faculty mentors that drew from a range of approaches (classical biochemical and genetic to non-trivial theoretical models that require computation) to study naturally-occurring genetic networks, artificial genetic and metabolic networks, and biomolecular structure, function, and evolution. Faculty from diverse departments served as mentors, including faculty within the Departments of Biosciences, Bioengineering, Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering, and Environmental Engineering. Students were frequently matched with faulty mentors who pursued similar undergraduate majors, which was done to catalyze discussions of the ways in which diverse majors can support cutting-edge biological research. Individual development plans were used to help students reflect on the activities needed to achieve their career goals.

In this program, students conducted full-time laboratory research and participated in seminars and workshops with topics ranging from responsible conduct in research and professional communication skills to career opportunities and the graduate school application process. Additional activities included attendance of faculty presentations on bionetworks research, meetings with graduate students pursuing diverse bionetworks research topics, and cohort building activities. Students were provided a creative opportunity to develop innovative technological ideas in small groups, as well as a capstone research poster symposium. The group projects within this REU site provided a unique creative outlet for students, which they typically do not experience in standard research projects. By having the students work in small multidisciplinary groups, we fostered student-student interactions across disciplines and exposed students to the benefits and challenges required by today’s team approach to projects.
